To Create a Landed Cost Document To allocate landed costs among items of either purchase receipts or transfer receipts, you create a landed cost document on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO303000|PO303000]) Landed Costs (PO303000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. To Create a Purchase Order Open the ([~/?ScreenId=PO303000|PO303000]) Landed Costs (PO303000) form by searching for or navigating to it. Select the landed cost vendor in the Vendor box. Check the location of the vendor, and change it if needed. Optional: In the Currency box, heck the currency and the currency exchange rate; change these, if needed. Check the date of the purchase order, and change it if needed. Optional: In the Vendor Ref. box, specify the reference number of the vendor's original document. (This value may be required, based on your organization's settings.) Optional: Select the Create Bill box, if you want the system to generate the Accounts Payable bill automatically on release of the landed cost document. Specify a short description of the landed cost document. To add all lines of documents to which the landed costs should be allocated, on the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add PO Receipt , and do the following in the Add Receipt dialog box, which opens: In the Type box, select Receipt to display purchase receipts in the table, or Transfer Receipt to display transfer receipts. Select the unlabeled check boxes in the rows with the receipts whose lines should be added. Click Add & Close to add the lines of the receipts and close the dialog box. To add the particular lines of either purchase receipts or transfer receipts to which the landed costs should be allocated, on the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add PO Receipt Line , and do the following in the Add Receipt Line dialog box, which opens: In the Type box, if it is available, select Receipt to display purchase receipts in the table, or Transfer Receipt to display transfer receipts. Select the unlabeled check boxes in the rows with the receipt lines to be added. Click Add & Close to add the selected receipt lines and close the dialog box. On the Document Details tab, review the information in the added lines, and make changes to weight and volume in lines, if needed. On the Landed Costs tab, for each landed cost amount that you want to allocate to the added receipt lines, click Add Row on the table toolbar, and do the following: In the Branch column, ensure that the system has specified the correct branch. In the Landed Cost Code column, select the landed cost code. In the Amount column, specify the landed cost amount to be allocated. Optional: In the Tax Category box, change the appropriate tax category if the landed cost amounts are subject to taxes. Optional: In the Inventory ID box, select a particular item if the landed cost amount should be allocated to only lines with this particular item ID. Click Save on the form toolbar. Clear the Hold check box in the Summary area. Click Save on the form toolbar.

To Add Landed Costs to a Bill To add line or lines of a landed cost document to an Accounts Payable bill to a landed cost vendor, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. To Add a Landed Cost Line to Bill Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form by searching for or navigating to it. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. In the Type box, select Bill , and select the needed bill by its reference number. On the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click Add LC . In the Add LC dialog box, which opens, do the following: Optional: Filter the lines in the table by selecting any of the following: the particular landed cost document in the LC Nbr. box, the particular receipt in the Receipt Nbr. box, or the particular landed cost code in the LC Code box. In the table, select the unlabeled check boxes in the line or lines with the landed costs to be added to the bill. Click Add & Close to close the dialog box and add the selected lines. On the Document Details tab, review the added lines, and correct their Ext. Cost , if needed. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. Notes About the Procedure The notes in this section describe the nuances of the UI elements available on the form, such as when an element is required and when it is not, and when the system fills in settings by default. This section can include other notes. Note the following about adding landed costs to a bill: The Add LC dialog box shows the lines of released landed cost documents for which the AP bill wasn't created on release. If you correct the landed cost amount in the bill, the occurred difference between the estimated amount in the landed cost document and corrected amount billed to landed cost vendor is posted to the Landed Cost Variance account. For details, see Adjusting the Landed Cost Variance.

To Link a Bill Line to Landed Cost Document To link a particular line of an existing Accounts Payable bill to a line of landed cost document, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form. To Link an Accounts Payable Bill to Landed Cost Document Open the ([~/?ScreenId=AP301000|AP301000]) Bills and Adjustments (AP301000) form by searching for or navigating to it. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. In the Type box, select Bill , and select the needed bill by its reference number. On the table toolbar of the Document Details tab, click a line with an empty inventory ID to which a landed cost should be linked, and click Link Line on the table toolbar. In the Link Line dialog box, which opens with the Landed Cost mode selected, select the unlabeled check box next to the landed cost line to be linked. Click Add & Close to close the dialog box and link the selected line. Optional: Correct the Ext. Cost of the bill line, if needed. Click Save to save your changes. Notes About the Procedure The notes in this section describe the nuances of the UI elements available on the form, such as when an element is required and when it is not, and when the system fills in settings by default. This section can include other notes. Note the following about adding landed costs to a bill: You can link a landed costs line to a line with empty Inventory ID only. Once you have linked a landed cost line, the description of a bill line changes to the description of the linked landed cost. Each bill line can be linked to only one landed cost line. The Link Line dialog box shows the lines of released landed cost documents for which the Accounts Payable bill wasn't created on release. If the amount in the bill line differs from the amount in the landed cost line that you linked, the occurred difference is posted to the Landed Cost Variance account. For details, see Adjusting the Landed Cost Variance.

row.PlainText: Processing Purchase Requisitions The Purchase Requisitions module, a part of the inventory and order management functionality, provides your organization with ability to create and process requests for goods and services, approve requests, and prevent cost overruns. The Purchase Requisitions module provides configurable, budget-compliant request documents. Also, the module facilitates a bidding process. The purchase requisitions functionality is available only if the Purchase Requisitions feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. If available, this module is integrated with the financial modules, as well as with the Inventory and Purchase Orders modules. This chapter contains information you need to configure and use the purchase requisitions functionality. In This Chapter Basic Purchase Requisition ProcessExtended Purchase Requisition ProcessProcessing and Selection of Bids

row.column: Basic Purchase Requisition Process An organization may want to pursue a clear, cost-efficient purchasing process that prioritizes the purchase of items from the most appropriate vendors at the best possible time and in the right quantities. To facilitate this process, an organization can use purchase requests and requisitions—that is, documents that track the items the organization wants to purchase from vendors. In Acumatica ERP, you can create requests, create purchase requisitions based on these requests, and solicit bids from multiple vendors so that your personnel can select the best bid. To use the requisition functionality, you must have the Purchase Requisitions feature enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In this topic, you will find information about the basic process of purchase requisitions in Acumatica ERP. Request Classes in Acumatica ERPA request class is an entity in Acumatica ERP that contains the general settings for requests of a particular type. You can create a request class on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ201000|RQ201000]) Request Classes (RQ201000) form and specify the following settings for the class: What the promised lead time is: In the Promised Lead Time (days) box (Summary area), you specify the number of days within which a request of the class should be fulfilled. Whether requests of the class are external or internal: External requests contain items requested by customers of your organization. To indicate that the request class will be used for external requests, you select the Customer Request check box in the Summary area. Internal requests are initiated by employees of your organization and contain items that the employees need in their work. Whether the items from a request of the class can be divided among multiple vendors: If a request contains multiple items, you can order these items from multiple vendors if one vendor cannot fulfill the entire request or if another vendor has lower prices for particular items. You select the Allow Multiple Vendors per Request check box, also in the Summary area, to indicate that the system can suggest multiple vendors to fulfill the request. Which items are available for ordering in requests of this class (optional): You can restrict the list of items that users can add to the request during creation to reduce the probability of mistakenly added items. To do this, you select the Restrict Requests Items to the Specified List check box in the Summary area, and you add the items to the list on the Request Class Item List tab. Whether the request must be validated against the budget: If you control expenses on particular items by using budgets, you can set up budget validation on the GL Accounts tab by selecting Warning or Error in the Budget Validation box (the default setting is None ) and specifying an expense account in the Expense Account box (and the corresponding subaccount, if applicable, in the Expense Sub. box). Purchase Requisition Usage In a simple case of using purchase requests and requisitions, you create one request or multiple requests, and then you create a purchase requisition based on the requests, manually select a vendor, and purchase items from this vendor (see the following diagram). You can use this simplified process, for example, when employees of your organization order low-cost items, such as office supplies. If you already work with a vendor that gives your company the best prices and discounts for these items, you do not need to gather bids from multiple vendors to save on price. Overview of the simplified requisition process If your organization works with multiple vendors that provide you with the same type of items (such as computers), you can request and process vendor bids to select the best offers. For example, if you have received an order for laptops from your employees, you can find a vendor or multiple vendors with the lowest prices to fulfill the order. Depending on the business processes of your organization, you can use budget validation for requests or approvals for requests and requisitions to secure the purchase requisitions process against fraud and unnecessary expenses. For more information, see Extended Purchase Requisition Process. Basic Purchase Requisition Process The basic purchase requisition process includes the following steps (also shown in the diagrams below): Creating a request: You create a request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) form. Creating a purchase requisition based on one request or multiple requests: You create a purchase requisition on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) form. Sending proposals to vendors by email (optional): You automatically send requests for proposals to vendors by email by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. Selecting a vendor (or multiple vendors) for the purchase: If you manually select a vendor (or multiple vendors for different items) for the requisition, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. If you have run automatic bidding, you analyze and correct the automatic bidding results by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form. For details on selecting vendors, see Processing and Selection of Bids. Creating all needed purchase orders (and, optionally, all needed sales orders for external requests): You create these orders by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. Sending all purchase orders that have been created to the applicable vendors: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders (PO301000) form, you send the created purchase order or orders to the vendor or vendors selected to fulfill the requisition. Receiving items in a warehouse: You create and process the documents related to the items being received in a warehouse by using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders and ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) forms. Providing items to requesters: For external requests, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=SO302000|SO302000]) Shipments (SO302000) forms to create and process the documents for shipping items to customers. For internal requests, you can create and process the documents for issuing items to employees of your organization by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000) form. Overview of requisition process with bids (part 1) Overview of requisition process with bids (part 2) Creation of a Purchase Requisition Document After the requests have been created, you create a requisition document. You can include multiple requests in one requisition if the items in these requests will be ordered from the same vendors. For creating a requisition, you can use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions form, you can create any number of requisitions. While on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form, you can fully process a requisition (from creation to release). When the system is creating a requisition, it can merge lines with the same items into one line if the item was requested by the same requester (a customer or an employee) and has the same estimated unit cost. If you want the system to merge items in all requisitions, you can select the Merge Lines by Default check box on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. Before you create any requisitions on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions form, you can select the Merge Lines check box in the Selection area to merge items for created requisitions, or clear the check box to not merge items. If a requisition has already been created, you can merge lines manually on the Document Details tab of the Requisitions form by selecting the Included check box for the lines in the list and clicking Merge Lines on the table toolbar. With manual merging in this way, the system will merge lines even if they have different unit costs and requesters. For external requests, we do not recommend that you merge items requested by different customers, because this may cause sales documents to be linked incorrectly to purchase requisitions. Sending of Requests for Proposals If you have email functionality configured in the system, you can automatically send requests for proposals to vendors by email by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form. To do this, on the Bidding tab, you select a vendor in the Bidding Vendors table and click Send Request . Alternatively, you can send requests to all vendors at once by clicking Vendor Notifications Send All Requests on the form toolbar. Extended Purchase Requisition Process If your organization takes measures to secure the purchasing process against fraud and unnecessary expenses, in Acumatica ERP, you can configure validation of requests against budget and approval of requests and requisitions as extensions of the basic process. In this topic, you will read about the extended process of purchase requisitions. Advanced Purchase Requisition Process The purchasing process that involves budget validation and approval of requests and requisitions includes the following steps (also shown in the diagrams below): Creating a request: You create a request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) form. Validating a request against a budget: You analyze the validation results on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form and correct the list of items if the request cost exceeds the budget. Approving the request: The employee that is assigned as the request approver approves or rejects the request by using the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals (EP503010) or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form. Creating a purchase requisition based on one request or multiple requests: You create a purchase requisition on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ504000|RQ504000]) Create Requisitions (RQ504000) form. Approving the requisition: The assigned requisition approver approves or rejects the requisition by using the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals or ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests form. Sending notifications to vendors: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form, you send a request for proposal to each vendor that may opt to participate in bidding by clicking the vendor on the Bidding tab (in the Bidding Vendors table) and clicking Send Request on the table toolbar. Entering vendor responses: You enter vendor responses into the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. Running automatic bidding: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form, you run automatic bidding among vendors. Selecting a vendor (or multiple vendors) for the purchase: You use the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form to manually select a vendor (or multiple vendors for different items) for the requisition. If you have run automatic bidding, you analyze and correct the automatic bidding results by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form. Creating all needed purchase orders (and, optionally, all needed sales orders for external requests): You create these orders from the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions form. Sending all purchase orders that have been created to the applicable vendors: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders (PO301000) form, you send the created purchase order or orders to the vendor or vendors selected to fulfill the requisition. Receiving items in a warehouse: You create and process the documents related to the items being received in a warehouse by using the ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders and ([~/?ScreenId=PO302000|PO302000]) Purchase Receipts (PO302000) forms. Providing items to requesters: For external requests, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=SO302000|SO302000]) Shipments (SO302000) forms to create and process the documents for shipping items to customers. For internal requests, you create and process the documents for issuing items to employees of your organization by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000) form. Process of purchase requisitions with budget validation and approval (part 1) Process of purchase requisitions with budget validation and approval (part 2) Request and Requisition Approvals In the system, you can create approval maps so that requests that meet particular criteria are submitted for approval to the appropriate employees. For example, if the total cost of the items in a request exceeds a particular amount, the request must be approved by the head of the department whose employee requested the items. You can configure the system so that particular requisitions or all requisitions require approval. For example, approval can be set up so that all requisitions that contain computer equipment that costs more than a particular amount must be approved by the IT department before purchasing can take place. Before you turn on the approval of requests and requisitions, you should make sure that the needed approval maps and notification templates (if needed) have been configured. The approval map defines the employees designated for approving documents and the conditions that the documents must meet (if applicable) to be assigned for approval; the template of the notification email will be used by the system for notifying approvers about the documents pending their approval. You then enable the approval of purchase requests or requisitions on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form by selecting the appropriate Require Approval check box (in the Request Settings or Requisition Settings section). Then on the Approval tab of this form, for each document type (request or requisition), you specify the approval map and, optionally, the template of the notification email. For the step-by-step instruction, see To Set Up Approval of Requests and Requisitions. With approvals turned on, when a purchase request or requisition that is subject to approval has been created, taken off hold, and saved, the document is assigned the Pending Approval status. The responsible approver receives an email notification (if an email notification template has been specified for this type of document) about the document pending approval. On the ([~/?ScreenId=EP503010|EP503010]) Approvals (EP503010) form, an approver can review the list of documents pending approval, and can select one record or multiple records in the list and approve or reject all selected records. To be able to approve requests and requisitions, an approver must have access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ301000|RQ301000]) Requests (RQ301000) and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) forms accordingly. If the document is approved, the system assigns it the Open status, and document processing can continue. If the document is rejected, it is assigned the Rejected status, and you cannot continue processing the document. You can edit the document after you select the Hold check box on the corresponding form. Budget Validation for Requests If your organization allocates budgets for valuable internal purchases, you can configure budget validation for requests to prevent cost overruns of requested goods and services. An employee who is creating a request can see whether the cost of the items included in the request is below the budget. If the cost exceeds the budget, the employee can edit the list of items in the request. Before you set up this validation, you should make sure that the budgets have been created and released in the system on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL302010|GL302010]) Budgets (GL302010) form. The setup of budget validation for requests includes the following tasks: Defining the way the system will calculate the costs of items included in a request: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form, in the Budget Ledger box of the General Settings tab, you select the budget ledger that the system will use for verification. You can also specify the time period over which the system will aggregate amounts from all requests created. In the Budget Calculation box, you select one of the following options: YTD Values : Calculates the total cost of requests created from the beginning of the financial year to the end of the current financial period PTD Values : Calculates the total cost of requests created from the beginning of the financial period Annual : Calculates the total cost of requests created for the current calendar year Turning on budget validation in the settings of each needed request class: On the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ201000|RQ201000]) Request Classes (RQ201000) form, you turn on budget validation by selecting the appropriate option in the Budget Validation box of the GL Accounts tab. (The default setting is None .) If you select Warning , a user will be able to save a request of this class even if the requested amount exceeds the budgeted amount, but the system will display a warning. If you select Error , a user will not be able to save a request of this class with an amount that exceeds the budgeted amount, and the system will display an error message. Processing and Selection of Bids The bidding process entails sending requests for proposals to vendors and choosing the vendor that best meets your company's needs. The Purchase Requisitions module of Acumatica ERP supports and streamlines the bidding process, helping you to reduce purchase expenses. You can manually assign a vendor to the requisition or select the vendor as a result of the bidding process. In this topic, you will read about how to process and select bids. Bid Processing You begin the processing of vendors' bids for a particular requisition when you receive responses (that is, bids) from vendors. The processing involves the following steps: You enter responses into the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. You select the best bids in any of the following ways: By using the automatic algorithm of selecting the best bids. This algorithm uses information about vendor's prices, minimal quantities, and bid quantities of the requested items. For more details, see Automatic Selection of Bids Automatic Selection of Bids. By analyzing responses and selecting vendors manually. For details, see Manual Selection of Bids Manual Selection of Bids. Automatic Selection of Bids You process the bids for a particular requisition by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) form. To run automatic bidding, you click Update Result on the form toolbar. The system selects a vendor or multiple vendors for each item automatically based on the offered price (bid unit cost) and the quantity limitations (bid quantity), if any, from vendor responses. You can view bidding results and correct them if you are not satisfied with the automatically selected vendors. If any vendor response has changed or been withdrawn after the system selected vendors for a requisition, you enter new responses on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form. Then you go back to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form, click Clear Result on the form toolbar to clear the selected vendors for all lines of a requisition, and click Update Result again. After you have analyzed and corrected the bidding results, you accept the results by clicking Complete Bidding on the toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding form. The system assigns the selected vendor or vendors to the requisition. Manual Selection of Bids When selecting the best bids, you may want to analyze the bidding responses and select the bids manually. You may want to take into account not only the vendor offering the lowest price but also any of the following: The number of days needed to deliver the order The carrier used by a vendor The shipping terms used by a vendor Special offers from a vendor You can select a vendor with a better bid by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) form as follows: You click the vendor line in the Bidding Vendors table on the Bidding tab and click Choose Vendor on the table toolbar. User Roles for Bid Processing To avoid fraud in selecting bids, you can control which employees can view bidding responses and results. If you want particular users to only enter bidding results, you create a user role that has access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form and does not have access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding (RQ503000) and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions (RQ302000) forms and assign this role to the users. For users who are selecting the best bids you create a user role with access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000]) Complete Bidding and ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) Requisitions forms and without access to the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) Bidding Responses (RQ303000) form and assign this role to the users. For more information, see Access Rights for Roles. ([~/?ScreenId=RQ302000|RQ302000]) ([~/?ScreenId=RQ303000|RQ303000]) ([~/?ScreenId=RQ503000|RQ503000])

To Set Up Approval of Requests and Requisitions For many businesses, approval of requests and requisitions is essential. In Acumatica ERP, you can set up approval for requests only, requisitions only, or for both types of documents. You can set up approval of requests and requisitions by using the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Before you proceed with enabling approval, make sure the following steps are completed: Make sure that the Approval Workflow check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Make sure that needed approval maps and notification templates (if needed) have been configured as described in Managing Assignment and Approval Maps. The approval map defines the employees designated for approving documents and the conditions that documents must match to be assigned for approval; the template of the notification email will be used by the system for notifying approvers about the documents pending their approval. You need to configure both the approval map and the notification template before you start to set up the approval process on the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences form. To Set Up Approval for Requests Open the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form by searching for or navigating to it. On the General Settings tab of this form, in the Request Settings section, select the Require Approval check box. On the Approval tab, If you have configured an approval map for requests, add it as follows: Click Add Row . In the Type column, select Request . In the Approval Map column, select the approval map to be used for requests. If no map is selected for requests, all new requests will be automatically approved. In the Pending Approval Notification column, select the email template you created for generating emails about requests that are pending approval. If multiple parallel approvals are required for requests, repeat Step 3 for each of the approval maps. Click Save on the form toolbar. To Set Up Approval for Requisitions Open the ([~/?ScreenId=RQ101000|RQ101000]) Purchase Requisitions Preferences (RQ101000) form by searching for or navigating to it. On the General Settings tab of this form, in the Requisition Settings section, select the Require Approval check box. On the Approval tab, if you have configured an approval map for requisitions, add it as follows: Click Add Row . In the Type column, select Requisition . In the Approval Map column, select the approval map to be used for requisitions. If no map is selected for requisitions, all new requisitions will be automatically approved. In the Pending Approval Notification column, select the email template you created for generating emails about requisitions that are pending approval. If multiple parallel approvals are required for requisitions, repeat Step 3 for each of the approval maps. Click Save on the form toolbar.

Automating Warehouse Operations On Acumatica ERP forms designed to facilitate automated warehouse operations, you can perform warehouse operations in an automated mode by using barcode scanners or mobile devices with a scanning option. If the Automated Warehouse Operations feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can automate standard warehouse operations with inventory items, such as picking, packaging, receiving, putting away, transferring, and counting. Depending on the operation that you are currently performing, you can switch between working modes on the current form or navigate to another form by using special barcodes. You can also configure carts to be used for picking and putting away the items, to track item movements between the warehouse locations. You can quickly review information for particular items, carts, and warehouses by scanning a barcode. The topics of this chapter describes the workflows that you can configure, depending on the business requirements of your company, to support automated processing of shipping, receiving, and inventory operations. In This Chapter Automation of Warehouse OperationsWorking Modes and Supported CommandsPick, Pack, and Ship OperationsReceive and Put Away OperationsScan and Count OperationScan and Issue OperationScan and Receive OperationScan and Transfer OperationWarehouse Operations with Lot- and Serial-Tracked ItemsCart Tracking in Warehouse Operations

Automation of Warehouse Operations Acumatica ERP provides a solution to automate basic warehouse operations, such as picking, packaging, receiving, putting away, transferring, and counting of items. This functionality and the related forms become available if the Automated Warehouse Operations feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In this topic, you will read about the automation of warehouse operations in Acumatica ERP. Supported Warehouse Operations You can automate the following warehouse operations by using a barcode scanner or a mobile device with barcode scanning support: Picking the items for a particular shipment. For details, see Pick, Pack, and Ship Operations. Packing the items to fulfill a particular shipment, as described in Pick, Pack, and Ship Operations. Shipping items based on a shipment defined in the system. For details, see Pick, Pack, and Ship Operations. Receiving items based on a purchase receipt defined in the system. (See Receive and Put Away Operations.) Putting away received items based on a purchase receipt. For more information, see Receive and Put Away Operations. Issuing items from a warehouse. For details, see Scan and Issue Operation. Transferring items within a warehouse or between warehouses located in the same building , as described in Scan and Transfer Operation. Receiving items in a warehouse. For details, see Scan and Receive Operation. Counting items within the physical inventory. For details, see Scan and Count Operation. In the system, a working mode corresponds to each of these operations (for more information, see Working and Service Modes Working and Service Modes). You can configure the workflow for each group of operations, as described in Workflow Configuration Workflow Configuration. Working and Service Modes The forms you use for automated warehouse operations provide both working modes and service modes . Working modes are modes that correspond to key operations users perform while using the form. Service modes are modes that correspond to secondary operations, such as removing document lines. Some forms that support the automation of warehouse operations, such as ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020), have multiple working modes. Each mode of a form, which corresponds to the operation you are currently performing, shows different content and supports a different set of actions. Other forms, such as ([~/?ScreenId=IN304020|IN304020]) Scan and Transfer (IN304020), have only one working mode, so that you can perform only a particular operation by using this form. While you are performing warehouse operations, you can change the working mode on the current form or navigate from the current form to another form by entering special commands (or by scanning special barcodes) starting with @. For example, if you scan or enter @pack in the Scan box (which is on all of the forms related to automated warehouse operations), the system navigates to the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) in Pack mode. When you change the mode of a form, the system keeps the current document selected. For example, if you have entered the shipment number in Pick mode and have entered the command (or have scanned the barcode) to switch to Pack mode, the system automatically selects the current shipment. On each form related to automated warehouse operations, you can activate any of the following service modes: Quantity Editing: In this mode, you can change a quantity of an item in the selected line. You activate the mode by scanning the *qty barcode or by clicking Set Qty on the form toolbar. This mode is available if the Use Default Quantity check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) and ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) forms and the Use Default Quantity in ... check boxes are cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. Remove: In this mode, you can remove the selected document line or a specific quantity of the inventory item from the current document. You activate the mode by scanning the *remove barcode or by clicking Remove on the form toolbar. Cart-specific modes: Cart Loading: In this mode, you load the selected cart with items. When you start picking or putting away items by using a cart, the system activates this mode automatically. If you want to activate this mode after unloading a cart, you scan the *cart*in command while using the corresponding form. Cart Unloading: In this mode, you unload the selected cart. You activate the mode by scanning the *cart*out command. In addition to having multiple modes, each of the forms provided by the Automated Warehouse Operations feature has the Scan Log tab, which shows a log of the data scanned or entered in the Scan box. (Depending on preferences of the forms related to purchase orders and sales orders functionality, this tab can be hidden.) Workflow Configuration You can configure the workflow for each group of related operations so that the workflow corresponds to the business processes of your organization. For example, when shipping items, you can use only the Pick, Pack, or Ship mode, use them in any combination, or use all the modes in the same workflow. When receiving items with a purchase order, you can use either the Receive mode or the Put Away mode, or you can use both modes in one workflow. Additionally, you can track the use of carts for picking and putting away items (for more details, see Cart Tracking in Warehouse Operations). For more information about workflow configuration and other settings, see Configuration of Warehouse Operation Workflows. Special Commands for Scanning When you work in any of the modes, you can use special commands to quickly switch to another mode or to perform an action in the current mode. You can scan a barcode of the command or type the command in the Scan box of a processing form. For the list of commands, see Working Modes and Supported Commands. Operations with Lot- and Serial-Tracked Items If the Lot and Serial Tracking feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, while using the forms that facilitate the automated processing of warehouse operations, you can process items with lot or serial numbers in any mode. For details, see Warehouse Operations with Lot- and Serial-Tracked Items. Support of Automatic and Manual Packaging If the Automatic Packaging feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, while you are performing picking and packing operations on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form, you specify the packaging options for the order manually. If the Automatic Packaging feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, when you process a shipment in Pick mode, all applicable boxes are selected and confirmed, and the box weight is specified automatically. If a single box was automatically specified for a shipment while you picked the items, then in Pack mode, the system automatically specifies the packaging details and confirms the box. Shipments for which multiple boxes were assigned cannot be packed automatically; you have to manually specify the packaging details and confirm the boxes. For a description of the picking and packing processes, see Pick, Pack, and Ship Operations. Search for Items As you perform any of the warehouse operations, you may need to search for items. For example, you might find a box that is not in storage and want to get information about what is in the box, or you may need to view the full list of items in a specific location or cart. To get information about a particular item by scanning the item barcode, you can use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202520|IN202520]) Item Lookup (IN202520) form. If you want to view the list of items in a specific location or a cart, you can scan the barcode of the location or cart when the ([~/?ScreenId=IN409020|IN409020]) Storage Lookup (IN409020) form is opened on the screen of your device. You can switch to either of these forms in any of the working modes by scanning or typing the corresponding command. For the list of commands, see Working Modes and Supported Commands.

Pick, Pack, and Ship Operations If the Fulfillment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can perform automated picking, packing, and shipping operations with inventory items by using a barcode scanner or a mobile device with a scanning option. This topic describes the workflows of automated operations that you can configure in Acumatica ERP for processing shipments. Applicable Documents You perform automated operations for processing shipments on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form. You can process the following documents in Pick mode: Open shipments of the Shipment operation type (shipments prepared for sales orders) Open shipments of the Transfer operation type (shipments prepared for transfer orders) Open shipments of the Receipt operation type (shipments prepared for return orders) In Pack mode, you can process open shipments of the Shipment or Transfer operation type. (If the picking of items is required before packing, the shipment must have at least one picked item.) Workflow Variations Based on the settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form, the following shipping workflow variations can be configured and used: A user processes the picking of items in Pick mode, and then processes the packing of items in Pack mode. In Pick mode, a user processes the picking of items and confirms the shipment. In Pack mode, a user processes the packing of items (without first picking them) and confirms the shipment. In Pick mode, a user processes the picking of items and enters a shipping location for each item. In Pack mode, a user processes the packing of items, and the system automatically calculates weight of each package. In addition, in any of these workflow variations, the user can switch to Ship mode (see Workflow of Automated Shipping Workflow of Automated Shipping) before confirming the shipment, and select shipping options, such as the particular carrier and carrier rate to be used for shipping. For more information on configuring workflows, see Configuration of Warehouse Operation Workflows. Workflow of Automated Picking The automated processing of the picking of items to be packed involves the actions shown in the following diagram. To process the picking of items by using Pick mode, you perform the following steps: Switch to Pick mode . You switch to Pick mode by scanning or entering the @pick barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form with the Pick tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of the shipment to be processed. The system displays the lines of the scanned document in the table and inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing in the Shipment Nbr. box. Scan the location barcode . When you scan the barcode of the location from which the item is picked, the system searches for the location in the lines of the document that is currently selected. Scan the item barcode . When you scan the item barcode of the picked item, the system searches for the item in the lines of the currently selected document. The system displays the picked quantity in the Picked Qty. column and highlights the line (with bold if the line has been picked partially, or in green if the line has been picked in full). If the barcode of the scanned item is specified for a non-base unit of measure (UOM), the system converts this quantity to the picked quantity in the base unit of measure for this item. Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked item, and only if the Default Auto-Generated Lot/Serial Nbr. check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form. If the check box is selected, the system specifies the lot or serial number for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the picked quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the UOM of the scanned item barcode. Optional: Scan the barcode to confirm the picked quantity . If no more changes are needed for the line that is currently being processed, you scan the *ok barcode or click the OK button to confirm the picked quantity. Pick another line . If another item needs to be picked for the currently selected location, you scan the item barcode (return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Pick items from another location . If you need to pick items from another location, you scan the location barcode (return to Step 3), and repeat the process for the location. Complete the picking process . If you have finished the picking operation and packaging is not needed, you scan the *confirm*shipment barcode or click the Confirm Shipment button on the form toolbar. The system confirms the shipment that is currently being processed. If you have finished the picking operation, to proceed with packaging, you scan the @pack barcode to switch to Pack mode. Workflow of Automated Packing Already-Picked Items The automated processing of packing items that have been picked involves the actions shown in the following diagram. To process the packing of items (and use Pack mode) after picking them, you perform the following steps: Switch to Pack mode . You switch to Pack mode by scanning or entering the @pack barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form with the Pack tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of shipment to be processed. (If you have switched to Pack mode from Pick mode with the document selected, the document is selected automatically.) The system shows the lines of the scanned document in the table and inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing in the Shipment Nbr. box. Scan the barcode of the box . You scan the barcode of the box into which the items will be packed. If the Automatic Packaging feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS101000) form, this step is performed automatically. Scan the item barcode . When you scan the barcode of the packed item, the system searches for the item in the lines of the document that is currently selected. If the barcode of the scanned item is specified for a non-base unit of measure, the system converts this quantity to the packed quantity in the base unit of measure for this item; the system also shows the packed quantity in the Packed Qty. column, and highlights the line (with bold if the line has been processed partially, or in green if the line has been processed in full). Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required if the item is lot- or serial-tracked, and only if the Default Auto-Generated Lot/Serial Nbr. check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form. If the check box is selected, the system specifies the lot or serial number for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the packed quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the UOM of the scanned item barcode. Pack another line . If another item needs to be packed in the current box, you return to scanning the item barcode (return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Confirm the box . If all items have been packed in the box, you confirm the current box by scanning the *ok barcode or by clicking the OK button. This step is performed automatically for the shipments that are being packed to a single box that the system has suggested automatically. Enter the box weight . You enter the total weight of the box. This step is performed automatically for the shipments that are being packed to a single box that the system has suggested automatically. Pack another box . If more items need to be packed for the current shipment, you return to scanning the barcode of the box barcode (return to Step 3), and repeat the process for another box. Complete the packing process . If you have finished the packing operation and specifying shipping options is not needed, you scan the *confirm*shipment barcode or click the Confirm Shipment button on the form toolbar. The system confirms the shipment that is currently being processed. If you have finished the packing operation and want to specify shipping options, you scan the @ship barcode to switch to Ship mode (see Workflow of Automated Shipping Workflow of Automated Shipping). Workflow of Automated Packing Without Picking The automated processing of directly packing items (without first picking them) involves the actions shown in the following diagram. To process the packing of items (and use Pack mode) without picking them, you perform the following steps: Switch to Pack mode . You switch to Pack mode by scanning or entering the @pack barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form with the Pack tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of the shipment to be processed. The system shows the lines of the scanned document in the table and inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing in the Shipment Nbr. box. Scan the barcode of the box . You scan the barcode of the box to which the items will be packed. If the Automatic Packaging feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS101000) form, this step is performed automatically. Scan the location barcode . When you scan the barcode of the location from which the item is being taken for packing, the system searches for the location in the lines of the document that is currently selected. Scan the item barcode . When you scan the item barcode of the packed item, the system searches for the item in the lines of the document that is currently selected. If the scanned item barcode corresponds to a non-base unit of measure, the system converts this quantity to the packed quantity in the base unit of measure for this item; the system also displays the packed quantity in the Packed Qty. column, and highlights the line (with bold if the line is processed partially, or in green if the line is processed in full). Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the lot or serial number of the packed item if the Default Auto-Generated Lot/Serial Nbr. check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form. If the check box is selected, the system specifies the lot or serial number for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the packed quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the UOM of the scanned item barcode. Pack another line . If another item needs to be packed in the current box, you return to scanning the item barcode (that is, return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Confirm the box . If all items are packed in the box, you confirm the current box by scanning the *ok barcode or by clicking the OK button. This step is performed automatically for the shipments that are being packed to a single box that the system has suggested automatically. Enter the box weight . You enter the total weight of the box. This step is performed automatically for the shipments that are being packed to a single box that the system has suggested automatically. Pack another box . If at least one other item needs to be packed for the current shipment, you return to scanning the barcode of the box (that is, return to Step 3), and repeat the process for another box. Complete the packing process . If you have finished the packing operation and you don't need to specify shipping options, you scan the *confirm*shipment barcode or click the Confirm Shipment button on the form toolbar. The system confirms the shipment that is currently being processed. If you have finished the packing operation, to select shipping options, you scan the @ship barcode to switch to Ship mode (see the following section). Workflow of Automated Shipping After you have picked and packed items, you perform the final shipping workflow. In this workflow, you specify shipping options and confirm the shipment, as shown in the following diagram. To specify shipping options for the shipment that is currently being processed, you perform the following steps: Switch to Ship mode . You switch to Ship mode by scanning or entering the @ship barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SO302020|SO302020]) Pick, Pack, and Ship (SO302020) form with the Ship tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of the shipment to be processed. The system inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing in the Shipment Nbr. box. (If you have switched to Ship mode from Pick mode or Pack mode with a document selected, the document is selected automatically.) The boxes for the shipment are shown in the Packages table. Select the carrier rate . In the Carrier Rates table, you select the unlabeled check box in the line of the carrier rate to be used for shipping. Optional: Generate return labels . On the table toolbar of the Carrier Rates table, click Get Return Labels to generate return labels for the shipment. Confirm the shipment . To confirm the processed shipment, you scan the *confirm*shipment barcode, or click the Confirm Shipment button on the form toolbar.

You need to scan the expiration date of the received item if the '''Default Expiration Date''' check box is cleared on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PO_10_10_00|Purchase Orders Preferences] form. If the check box is selected, the system fills in the expiration date for the serialized item automatically. #Optional: ''Scan the item quantity''. #:To change the received quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch on Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the <tt>*qty</tt> barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the base unit of measure. #Optional: ''Scan the barcode to confirm the received quantity''. #:If no more changes are needed for the line that is currently being processed, you scan the <tt>*ok</tt> barcode or click the '''OK''' button to confirm the received quantity. #''Receive another line''. #:If at least one other item needs to be received for the document currently being processed, you return to scanning the item barcode (that is, return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. #''Receive items in another location''. #:If items must be received in another warehouse location, you scan the barcode of this location (return to Step 3) and repeat the process for the next location. #''Complete the receiving process''. #:If you have finished the receiving operation but not all items have been received for the purchase receipt (and they will not be received in the future), you scan the <tt>*complete*polines</tt> barcode, or click the '''Complete PO Lines''' button. If the scanned item barcode is specified for a non-base unit of measure, the system converts this quantity to the quantity in the base unit of measure for this item. To indicate the line or lines with the scanned barcode, the system selects the '''Matched''' check box in these lines. Receive and Put Away Operations If the Receiving feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can perform automated receiving and putting away of inventory items by using a barcode scanner or a mobile device with a scanning option. This topic describes the workflows of automated operations that you can configure in Acumatica ERP for processing purchase documents. Applicable Documents You perform automated operations for processing purchase documents on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302020|PO302020]) Receive and Put Away (PO302020) form. You can process the following documents in Receive mode: Purchase orders with the Open status Purchase receipts with the Balanced status Purchase returns with the Balanced status In Put Away mode, you can process purchase receipts with the Released status. Workflow Variations Based on the settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) form, the following workflow variations can be configured and used for the automated receiving and putting away of inventory items: You process the receipt of items to the receiving location in Receive mode, and then process the putting away of items in storage locations in Put Away mode. In Receive mode, you receive items directly to a single storage location. In Put Away mode, you process the receipt of items to multiple storage locations. In Receive mode, you scan the barcode of the receiving location for each new item to be received. In Put Away mode, you scan the barcode of the destination location for each item to be put away. For more information on configuring workflows, see Configuration of Warehouse Operation Workflows. Workflow of Automated Receipt of Items The automated processing of the receipt of items involves the actions shown in the following diagram. To process the receipt of items (and to use Receive mode), you perform the following steps: Switch to Receive mode . You switch to Receive working mode by scanning or entering the @receive barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302020|PO302020]) Receive and Put Away (PO302020) form with the Receive tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of purchase order, purchase receipt, or purchase return document to be processed. The system displays the lines of the scanned document in the table. If you have scanned the purchase order number, the system creates and saves the related purchase receipt automatically. In the Receipt Nbr. box, the system inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing. Scan the barcode of receiving location . You scan the barcode of the warehouse location where items are being received. Scan the item barcode . When you scan the barcode of the received item, the system searches for the item in the lines of the document that is currently selected. If the item is found, the system highlights the line with bold. If the scanned item barcode corresponds to a non-base unit of measure, the system converts this quantity to the received quantity in the base unit of measure for this item. Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the lot or serial number of the received item if the Default Auto-Generated Lot/Serial Nbr. check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) form. If the check box is selected, the system inserts the lot or serial number for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan or enter the expiration date of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the expiration date of the received item if the Default Expiration Date check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences form. If the check box is selected, the system fills in the expiration date for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the received quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch on Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the base unit of measure. Optional: Scan the barcode to confirm the received quantity . If no more changes are needed for the line that is currently being processed, you scan the *ok barcode or click the OK button to confirm the received quantity. Receive another line . If at least one other item needs to be received for the document currently being processed, you return to scanning the item barcode (that is, return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Receive items in another location . If items must be received in another warehouse location, you scan the barcode of this location (return to Step 3) and repeat the process for the next location. Complete the receiving process . If you have finished the receiving operation but not all items have been received for the purchase receipt (and they will not be received in the future), you scan the *complete*polines barcode, or click the Complete PO Lines button. The system marks all purchase receipt lines as completed and releases the purchase receipt. If you have finished the receiving operation and all items have been received for the purchase receipt (or the items were received partially but more items will be received in the future), you scan the *release*receipt barcode or click the Release Receipt button. The system does not mark partially received lines as completed and releases the purchase receipt. Receipt of Extra Quantity If the actual quantity of received items is more than the quantity specified in the processed purchase document, you can process the receipt of these items as an automated operation as well. If you scan the quantity that exceeds the quantity in the line that is currently being processed, the system requests confirmation for adding this quantity. If you confirm this addition with the *ok barcode or the OK button, the system adds a new line with the extra quantity to the processed purchase receipt document, and shows this line in the table on the Receive tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302020|PO302020]) Receive and Put Away (PO302020) form. The line with the extra quantity is not linked to the purchase order for which the purchase receipt was prepared. Workflow of Automated Putting Away of Items The automated processing of putting away items involves the actions shown in the following diagram. To process the putting away of items by using Put Away mode, you perform the following steps: Switch to Put Away mode . You switch to Put Away mode by scanning or entering the @putaway barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=PO302020|PO302020]) Receive and Put Away (PO302020) form with the Put Away tab displayed. Scan the document number . To start automated processing, you scan the reference number of released purchase receipt to be processed. (If you switched to Put Away mode from Receive mode with a document selected, the system selected the document automatically.) The system displays the lines of the scanned document in the table. In the Receipt Nbr. box, the system inserts the reference number of the document that is currently selected for processing. Scan the barcode of the destination location . You scan the barcode of the destination location to which you are putting away items. If the items of a particular line are put away to multiple locations, the system creates line splits for the line. You can review the IDs of the locations to which the items are put away by clicking Transfer Allocations on the table toolbar of the Put Away tab. Once you have specified the destination location, the system automatically creates a one-step inventory transfer document that reflects the movement of the item from the receiving location to the storage location. Scan the barcode of the item . When you scan the item barcode of the received item, the system searches for the item in the lines of the document that is currently selected. If the scanned item barcode is specified for a non-base unit of measure, the system converts this quantity to the quantity in the base unit of measure for this item. To indicate the line or lines with the scanned barcode, the system selects the Matched check box in these lines. The system highlights in bold the lines that are processed partially, and in green if the line is processed in full. Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the lot or serial number of the item to be put away. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the put away quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode, and manually enter the quantity in the UOM of the scanned item barcode. Optional: Scan the barcode to confirm the quantity being put away . To confirm the quantity being put away, you scan the *ok barcode or click the OK button. Scan another item . If at least one other item needs to be put away, you return to scanning the barcode of the item (that is, return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Scan another destination location . If items must be transferred to another destination location, you scan the barcode of this location (return to Step 3) and repeat the process. Complete the put away process . When you have finished the operation of putting away items, you scan the *release*transfer barcode or clicks the Release Transfer button. The system releases the inventory transfer document that was prepared during the automated operation; the items are moved to the destination locations.

Scan and Count Operation If the Base Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can perform automated counting physical inventory by using a barcode scanner or a mobile device with a scanning option. This topic describes the workflow that you can configure in Acumatica ERP for the automated counting of inventory items. Overview of Automated Scanning and Counting The automated counting of inventory items involves the steps shown in the following diagram and described below. Workflow of Automated Scanning and Counting To count inventory items (and use Scan and Count mode), you perform the following steps: Switch to Scan and Count mode . You switch to Scan and Count mode by scanning or entering the @count barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=IN305020|IN305020]) Scan and Count (IN305020) form. Scan the document number To start automated counting, you scan the reference number of the physical inventory document. The lines of the scanned document are shown in the table. The reference number of the document selected for processing is displayed in the Reference Nbr. box. Scan the location barcode . You scan the barcode of the location where the items to be counted are stored. All items that you scan after scanning the location barcode will be assigned to this location. Scan the item barcode . When you scan the item barcode, the system changes the status of the line for this item to Entered . Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. Optional: Scan the expiration date of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. Optional: Scan the item quantity . To change the counted quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode or by clicking Set Qty on the form toolbar; you then manually enter the quantity in the base unit of measure. Optional: Scan the barcode to confirm the counted quantity . If the Use Explicit Line Confirmation check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, you confirm the line that is currently being processed by scanning the *ok barcode or by clicking OK on the form toolbar. Optional: Scan the barcode of the next item in the same location . If you have more items to count in the same location, you scan the barcode of the next item (return to Step 4) and repeat the process for the item. Optional: Scan the barcode of the next location . If items in another location must be counted, you return to scanning the warehouse location (return to Step 3) and repeat the process for the items in this location. Confirm the physical inventory count . When you have finished counting items, you scan the *confirm*document command or click Confirm on the form toolbar. The system saves your changes to the physical inventory document. ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN305020|IN305020])

Scan and Receive Operation If the Base Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can perform the automated receipt of inventory items by using a barcode scanner or a mobile device with a scanning option. This topic describes the workflow that you can configure in Acumatica ERP for the automated receipt of inventory items. Workflow Variations Based on the settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, the following workflow variations can be configured and used: You enter a barcode of a receiving location for each new item. You enter a reason code for each new line of an inventory receipt. You enter a quantity for all lines of the document once. For more information on configuring workflows, see Configuration of Warehouse Operation Workflows. Overview of Automated Scanning and Receiving The automated receiving of inventory items involves the steps shown in the following diagram and described below. Workflow of Automated Scanning and Receiving To receive items (and to use Scan and Receive mode), you perform the following steps: Switch to Scan and Receive mode . You switch to Scan and Receive mode by scanning or entering the @inreceive barcode. The system opens the ([~/?ScreenId=IN301020|IN301020]) Scan and Receive (IN301020) form. Scan the location barcode . When you scan the barcode of the receiving location, the system fills in the location ID in the Location column in the line that is currently being processed. Optional: Scan the warehouse barcode . If a location with the identifier scanned on the previous step is assigned to multiple warehouses, you scan the warehouse barcode. The system inserts the warehouse ID in the Warehouse box. Scan the item barcode . You scan the barcode of the item being received. Optional: Scan the lot or serial number of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the lot or serial number of the received item if the Use Default Auto-Generated Lot/Serial Nbr. check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. If the check box is selected, the system specifies the lot or serial number for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan the expiration date of the item . This step is required only if the item is lot- or serial-tracked. You need to scan the expiration date of the received item if the Use Default Expiration Date check box is cleared on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences form. If the check box is selected, the system specifies the expiration date for the serialized item automatically. Optional: Scan item quantity . To change the received quantity in the line that is currently being processed, you switch to Quantity Editing mode by scanning or entering the *qty barcode or by clicking Set Qty on the form toolbar; you then manually enter the quantity in base unit of measure. Optional: Scan the barcode to confirm the quantity being received . If the Use Explicit Line Confirmation check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences form, you confirm the line that is currently being processed by scanning the *ok barcode or by clicking OK on the form toolbar. Optional: Scan the barcode of the next item to be received . If more items need to be received, you return to scanning the item barcode (return to Step 4), and repeat the process for the item. Optional: Scan the barcode of the next location . If items must be received in another warehouse location, you scan the barcode of this location (return to Step 2) and repeat the process for the next location. Release the inventory receipt . When you have finished receiving items, you scan the *release*receipt command or click Release on the form toolbar. The system releases the inventory receipt.
